title: Check IP Address
scenario: Find out your system's IP address using the appropriate networking command.
hints: Use the command to view network interface information
It's commonly used on Unix/Linux systems

title: Ping Test
description: Test connectivity to a remote server
scenario: Check if google.com is reachable from your system.
hints: Use the ping command to test connectivity

title: Traceroute
description: Trace the path packets take to a host
scenario: Determine the route taken to reach example.com from your system.
hints: Use traceroute to follow the path packets take

title: Check Open Ports
description: See which ports are open on your system
scenario: Use a command to list all listening ports on your machine.
hints: The flags list TCP/UDP ports numerically

title: Display Routing Table
scenario: View the routing table to understand how network traffic is routed.
hints: Use route to display routing information

title: DNS Lookup
description: Resolve a domain to its IP address
scenario: Find the IP address of example.com using a DNS lookup command.

title: Display Active Connections
scenario: List all active connections along with the associated processes.
hints: Use ss to display socket statistics
Flags: -t for TCP, -u for UDP, -l for listening, -w for raw info

title: Check Network Interface Statistics
description: View detailed statistics of network interfaces
scenario: Display statistics like transmitted/received packets for all interfaces.
hints: Use ifconfig with the -s flag for summary
Shows a concise view of network stats

title: Test Port Reachability
description: Check if a remote port is open
scenario: Test if port 80 is open on example.com.
hints: The -z flag scans without sending data

title: Capture Network Packets
scenario: Capture packets on the eth0 interface using tcpdump.

title: Check Gateway
scenario: Determine the IP address of the default gateway your system uses.
hints: Use ip route to check routing info
Try typing: ip route | grep default

title: Test Bandwidth
description: Measure network bandwidth to a server
scenario: Use iperf3 to test the bandwidth to a remote server at 192.168.1.10.
hints: The -c flag specifies the client target

title: Monitor Network Traffic
description: Use nload to monitor live traffic
scenario: Monitor live incoming and outgoing traffic on eth0.
hints: nload is used for monitoring network usage

title: Check ARP Table
scenario: Display the ARP table of your system.
hints: Use arp to view ARP table

title: Network Debugging
description: Trace TCP connection issues using telnet
scenario: Test a TCP connection to port 443 on example.com.
hints: Use telnet to test TCP connectivity
